Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, she proposes to make third level education more accessible to the children of parents whose incomes are above grant eligibility levels.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress the higher education grants scheme will be re-examined in the context particularly of increasing the income eligibility limits for families with more than one child attending third level; assessing income eligibility of mature students who are not dependent on their parents, on the basis of their own and, if married, that of their spouses' incomes; the development of more equitable income assessment criteria for all applicants.

MainHeading.P: I am confident that these measures will further facilitate access of those most in need. The Deputy may be aware that there are at present over 50 per cent of students in third level in receipt of grant aid. In the VEC colleges the figures is in the order of 90 per cent. These figures indicate the extent to which third level access is already being facilitated by the various schemes of financial assistance to students.

Qst.Quest: the reason she has refused to allocate a grant to the town of Tralee VEC to extend the sports centre at Clounalour despite the fact that £300,000 was approved by her Department for the project in March 1989.
the reason she wishes to rescind the terms of an agreement drawn up between the Tralee VEC and Tralee UDC on 1 October 1980 for the management of Tralee sports complex.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 40 and 70 together.
A grant of £300,000 was approved in 1988 in respect of an extension to the Tralee sports complex under the Government's multi-annual capital programme funded by the national lottery.

My Department wish, however, to have the management arrangements for the complex re-examined to ensure, among other things, that it is operated on a self-financing basis an that no responsibility will lie with the VEC in respect of the operation and operating costs of the complex.

It will be necessary that the revised management structure be put in place before further proceeding with the proposed extension of the sports complex. Officials of my Department will shortly be inviting representatives of the VEC to discussions on the revised management structures.

Qst.Quest: if she will use her office to facilitate the re-introduction of "Teilifis Scoile" and adult education programmes on RTE.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of the re-introduction of “Teilifis Scoile” and the provision of adult education programmes on RTE is a matter for the RTE Authority.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Third Level Education Grants.

Qst.Quest: if, taking 1981 as the base year and accounting for all years to the end of 1990, she will outline the erosion in purchasing power or real value of third level education grants funded by her Department expressed in terms of parents' income and other family dependants, necessary to qualify for maximum and minimum grants at 1 October 1981 and 1 October 1990.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Based on indices provided by the Central Statistics Office, the consumer price index increased by 74.2 per cent between 1981 and 1990. Between 1981 and 1990 the value of a higher education grant payable at the maximum rate increased by £1,476 from £1,592 to £3,063. This represents an increase of 92.7 per cent. In the same period total expenditure on higher education grants increased from £3.4 million to £27.2 million, that is to say an increase of the order of 700 per cent. In the case of a family with one or two dependent children, the income limits in order to qualify for the maximum rate of grant have been increased by 31.4 per cent.

MainHeading.P: The means test tables are so framed as to give greater financial assistance to students from low-income families. The real value of a higher education grant has been maintained at a level of approximately 18 per cent ahead of the consumer price index in the period in question. Moreover, income eligibility limits have been increased in line with the CPI each year since 1985. In addition, I wish to point out that in the Programme for Government 1989 to 1993, the Government gave a commitment that income eligibility limits will continue to be index-linked.

All students qualifying for a maintenance grant automatically qualify for payment of full course fees. The fees payable under the scheme have increased in line with fee increases generally and so grantholders are unaffected by the fee increases during the full period of their third level courses.

Qst.Quest: if she will consider the provision of two post-primary schools in Portlaoise, County Laois, in view of the fact that the catchment area for the town in primary education has in excess of 2,200 pupils, and with a six year cycle being provided in the future in post-primary education, one school would be too large in Portlaoise.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The figure as quoted by the Deputy is not correct. The combined enrolment of the three schools in Portlaoise has declined from just over 1,300 in 1987-88 to 1,149 at present.

The need for rationalisation has been accepted by the managements of the three schools and discussions and consultations among all the interested parties, including parents and teachers have been conducted at local level.
The most recent statistical data available to the Department indicates that a single school development would most adequately cater for the future needs of the centre.

Recently I met representatives of the trustees of the schools to discuss this issue. I intend also to have discussions in the matter shortly with the parents' representatives and teacher representatives.

I do not wish to pre-empt the outcome of discussions at local level between myself and the other interested parties which have not yet been concluded. I would hope that a consensus on this issue will emerge.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Vocational Training Opportunities Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the guidelines, if any, which have been laid down for the expenditure of the £15,000 non-pay costs grant available to centres offering the vocational training opportunities scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It has been indicated to vocational education committees that the £15,000 non-pay is being provided to cover all VTOS non-pay costs other than allowances for which there is separate provision.

Qst.Quest: when the National General Forum of Local Groups will be convened to discuss the progress and problems of the vocational training opportunities scheme.

if local co-ordinating groups have been set up in all the vocational education committee areas which have vocational training opportunities scheme programmes; whether all the intended participants, including unemployed centres, have been involved; and where these have not been set up when they will be.

whether any consideration has been given to involving the Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed in the National General Forum which is to be established to monitor the vocational training opportunities scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 45, 58 and 77 together. Thirteen of the 24 vocational education committees who have vocational training opportunities scheme groups have set up local co-ordinating groups. Eight others are in course of setting them up and expect that they will be operating shortly. Vocational training opportunities scheme groups in the remaining three vocational education committees are not yet operational.

Where groups have been established all the intended participants have been involved including representatives from unemployed centres where there are such. Where there are no unemployed centres the unemployed are otherwise represented where it has been possible to arrange this. Course participants are represented on two groups and such representation is being arranged or under consideration in the case of a number of other groups. The convening of the general forum is under consideration at present and the question of involving the Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed in the forum will be examined.

Qst.Quest: whether any guidelines have been issued as to the manner in which the new allocation of moneys is to be spent for the zoo; if she will make a statement on the matter; if she will outline the legal owner of the zoo; whether the land is still under lease to the zoo; and the conditions appertaining to the lease.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In providing a grant of £670,000 to the zoo in December 1990, it was indicated to the zoo that the money was being provided towards their current deficit and towards the deficit that would arise in the off-season. It was also indicated that the zoo's financial liabilities to the Revenue Commissioners should be discharged without delay.
The other matters raised by the Deputy are matters for the Office of Public Works.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the concern of many parents over the shortage of secondary school places in the Castleknock area of County Dublin in view of the rapid population expansion in the area; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department are aware of the concern of some parents regarding the availability of post-primary school places for pupils from the Castleknock area of County Dublin.

Because of on-going housing developments in the area my Department have kept the position under annual review to take account of all relevant factors. These reviews indicate that for the present there are adequate post-primary school places available in adjoining areas to cater for the needs of the Castleknock area.
My Department will continue to review the position in Castleknock in the light of the most up-to-date data available on demographic trends, housing developments and primary school enrolments.

Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement on the present position regarding the proposed new post-primary school for Fingal community college.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The accommodation requirements of Fingal community college have been examined and a schedule of accommodation to be provided is currently under discussion with the County Dublin Vocational Education Committee.

Qst.Quest: whether she intends to provide greater resources for adult education agencies, particularly in the light of the increasing unemployment figures.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There have been very substantial increases in funding to the VEC's in the last few years for the vocational training and opportunities scheme, which is a scheme for the long term unemployed, and for the adult literacy and community education scheme. I am providing a substantial increase in funding again this year for the vocational training and opportunities scheme, together with increased funding for the adult literacy and community education scheme.

Important initiatives for disadvantaged adults and in particular for the long term unemployed will be taken under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress. Education agencies will be involved in these initiatives in co-operation with the other parties concerned. I have also provided significant additional funding for adult education bodies in recent years and I am increasing the grants for a number of these bodies again this year.

Qst.Quest: the proportion of (a) primary pupils, (b) VEC second level pupils and (c) voluntary secondary pupils accommodated in pre-fabricated classrooms; her views on whether these are an acceptable form of accommodation for pupils; the plans she has to phase these units out; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy regarding the proportion of pupils accommodated in prefabricated classrooms is not available.

Prefabricated buildings are intended to meet a short term temporary need and those grant aided or provided by my Department are designed to ensure a satisfactory standard of accommodation for this purpose. The recently agreed Programme for Economic and Social Progress contains a commitment that extra funding will be available from 1992 to 1997 to upgrade or replace all sub-standard buildings at primary and second level. A substantial amount of this will be devoted to the replacement of pre-fabricated facilities which are no longer considered satisfactory.

Qst.Quest: if an application has been received from Monard national school, County Tipperary, for the provision of a grant towards the installation of photocopying facilities for the infants class; if she will approve this application; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Monard national school has applied for a grant towards the purchase of a photo copier. However, it has not been possible to assist the school because of the limit on funding available for such purposes at present.
As the Deputy will be aware the primary education review body addressed the question of equipment in schools. My Department will be giving consideration to the points raised in this report.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Vocational Training Opportunities Scheme.

Qst.Quest: if there are any plans to expand vocational training opportunities scheme to those VEC areas which at present do not have them.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I plan to approve additional vocational training and opportunities scheme groups to operate from next autumn. The allocation of the groups has not been decided yet. In deciding on the allocation of groups, I will be taking account of the number of long term unemployed in various areas and the potential for a viable group being established.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the poor condition of St. Joseph's junior school, Balcurris, Dublin 11, with particular regard to the conditions of the roof and the surface of the play area; and the plans she has for an immediate improvement in conditions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I am aware of the situation in relation to conditions at St. Joseph's national school, Balcurris, Dublin 11. Qst.Quest: if she will make the necessary finance available to University College, Cork, so they can avoid raising student fees by 8 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The level of fees charged by the universities is a matter for the governing bodies of the individual colleges. However, I understand the increase referred to by the Deputy was decided by the governing body of UCC in order to bring their level of fees into line with the general level of university fees.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - College Access for Handicapped.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have had a particular personal interest in this case. I am, therefore, pleased to inform the Deputy that I have authorised works at Galway RTC, including the installation of a lift, to improve accessibility for disabled persons and wheelchair users.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware I have already authorised the school authorities to proceed with the final stage of architectural planning for the proposed new building at St. Mary's diocesan school.

Qst.Quest: if she will allocate funds in 1991 to Waterford Corporation to proceed with their three year programme for the development of Waterford regional sports centre.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: An application from Waterford Corporation for funding towards additional sports facilities at their existing sports centre at Kilbarry, Waterford, is under consideration by my Department.
A decision in the matter will be conveyed to Waterford Corporation as soon as possible.

Qst.Quest: if she has examined the rate of participation in third level education on a county by county basis; the plans she has, if any, to encourage and improve the rate of participation from those counties from the lowest levels; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I am aware of, and have examined, the data referred to by the Deputy which relate to new entrants in 1986. The percentage of students sitting the leaving certificate who transfer to third level education has increased significantly from 35 per cent in 1986 to approximately 45 per cent at present. This increase must reflect higher participation rates in all counties in the interim, including those counties with the lowest participation in 1986. This process will continue under the various measures to generally increase the number of third level places under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.
The advent of the new regional technical college in Tallaght should be of particular assistance in redressing the problem of lower than average participation in the Dublin area.

Retention at second level has been identified as one of the more significant predictors of third level participation rates. Under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress my Department will also be bringing forward specific measures under which disadvantaged second level schools will be targeted for special action designed to develop supportive linkages with third level in an effort to motivate and facilitate pupils of suitable ability to proceed to third level education. Arrangements will also be made to allocate third level places for students from disadvantaged areas.

My Department will continue to monitor the rates of participation by county and to that end are taking steps to have the data corresponding to that provided in the Clancy report of 1988 updated as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Schools for Young Offenders.

Qst.Quest: the number of persons in care in places of remand and assessment and in long-stay units under her Department's control at present; her views on whether the number of places is adequate; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There were 164 young persons in care on 8 March 1991 in the four special schools for young offenders under my Department's control. Due to the pressure for accommodation for both boys and girls, arrangements are being made at present to have 44 additional places provided at Lusk, County Dublin, this coming summer. In addition, a special centre for 20 girls is to be constructed at Finglas.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: the reason the VEC sector does not receive additional resources per student for increased student enrolment, as the Higher Education Authority sector did for 1990-91; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The additional resources for the university sector arose from an agreement reached with the university authorities. Under this agreement the universities will provide not less than 3,600 additional student places over the next three to four years by raising their intake quotas by not less than 1,200 additional places per annum over and above the historical pattern of growth. This agreement came into operation at the start of the present academic year.

While a similar arrangement was not put into effect for the VEC third-level colleges the financial allocation provided for the colleges for 1990-91 took into account the increased enrolments in 1990 and any anticipated increases for 1991. I am satisfied that the provision for that purpose is adequate.

Qst.Quest: the amount of additional funding allocated in respect of resources for the junior certificate in the school years 1989-90 and 1990-91; the way in which these moneys were distributed between secondary, community, comprehensive and vocational schools; and the headings under which the money was allocated.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In each of the years in question a total of £1 million of additional funding was made available to enable schools to equip themselves for the junior certificate subject.
The grant was calculated in proportion to the enrolment of each school subject to a minimum grant of nearly £470 for the smallest schools.

In addition to the grant in respect of the junior certificate, grants were also made, at the rate of £5,000 per school to schools selected to teach the subject junior technology at junior certificate level.
Grants totalling £310,000 and £280,000 were paid under this latter heading in 1989-90 and 1990-91 respectively.
I propose to circulate a tabular statement giving details of these grants.
Tabular Statement.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: the total number of students which it is projected will be enrolled in each of the regional technical colleges for the school years 1991-92 to 1999-2000 inclusive.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As a result of initiatives set out in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, the provision for third-level places will exceed the estimates furnished to the Deputy in response to Questions Nos. 186 and 187 of 4 November 1989.

Almost 9,000 additional places will be provided in the near term as a result of these initiatives. The position with regard to medium to longer-term needs will be kept under review, and the projections updated accordingly. In the circumstances, it would not be realistic at this time to attempt to project student enrolments by institution.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline in respect of voluntary secondary schools (a) the number and proportion of such schools which have a board of management, (b) the interests represented on the boards where they exist and (c) if her Department have laid down regulations and rules of procedure for such boards as in the case of national schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department do not keep specific records related to boards of management in voluntary secondary schools. I understand, however, that of the 485 such schools, 227, or 47 per cent, have boards of management.
In most cases, the membership of a board comprises representatives of school trustees, parents and teachers on the school staff.
No regulations or rules of procedure are laid down by my Department for such boards.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline her plans to improve the conditions at the School of the Divine Word, Marley Grange, Rathfarmham, Dublin 16; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that (a) the railing surrounding the school which has been worked on since last September is still incomplete, (b) that children have nowhere to play, (c) there are JCBs still in the school grounds and (d) abandoned cars have been dumped in the school grounds; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The undertaking of the works referred to by the Deputy at the Divine Word national school, Rathfarnham, Dublin 16 are matters for the school authorities.
On 20 July 1990 my Department authorised the school authorities to proceed with the provision of boundary fencing at the school on the basis of proposals and costings prepared by his consultants.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the number of vocational schools, secondary schools, community schools-colleges and comprehensive schools which have language laboratories; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There are no statistics in my Department on the availability of language laboratories in post-primary schools.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if she will outline her views on sex education in our schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In so far as sex education in school is a matter of supplementing the primary function of parents in this regard, it may be appropriately provided under health education and religious education.

I agree with the views expressed by the Primary Curriculum Review Body in their report indicating that health education is of sufficient importance to warrant inclusion in the primary school curriculum, that that should be done by treating it as a cross-curricular theme and that health education should include issues relating to sex education with due regard for the views of parents.

In regard to post-primary education my Department's policy is outlined in the document, “Guidelines on the development of Sex-Relationships Education”, which issued to post primary schools in 1987 and a copy of which I am making available to the Deputy.

Qst.Quest: the plans she has for a regional technical college to serve the growing population of Blanchardstown, County Dublin; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: when she intends to sanction the building of the regional technical college which was approved for Blanchardstown, County Dublin, which has a population of over 50,000, and is growing rapidly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 74 and 80 together.
The provision of places in universities, regional, technical and other third level colleges is kept under review in my Department.

The Deputies will be aware that under the terms of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress special initiatives will create almost 9,000 additional third level places within the period of the programme. Initiatives include the provision of 3,600 places in universities under arrangements initiated by the Government in the 1990 budget, the provision of funding to UCD for the acquisition of Carysfort College, 600+places at Belfield, the utilisation of spare capacity in the colleges of education, including Thomond College, involving linkages within the university system, 1,500 places, and the provision of a new regional technical college in Tallaght, County Dublin, and other third level facilities under the national development plan, 2,000 places. The possibility of a further 1,000 places being provided with private sector financial participation is being explored by one of the universities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Lottery Funding.

Qst.Quest: if she will list all the organisations which were allocated funds from the £34 million national lottery surplus by her Department in 1990; the amount which each organisation received; the type of project involved; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

row.entry: General expenses of youth organisations and other expenses in relation to youth activities

Qst.Quest: the number of second level schools which offer two modern continental languages to their pupils; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: For the school year 1988-89 the number of post-primary schools providing instruction in at least two modern languages was 364, which represents an increase of more than 65 per cent over the position in 1985-86. I believe these figures reflect both the importance which I have attached to meeting the demand for the provision of modern languages in our schools and the resources which I have made available to meet that demand. Given the particular importance surrounding the provision of modern languages in the context of European integration and the approach of 1992, I am, of course, committed to the continuing and improved provision of resources for these subjects. I am confident that, when data regarding modern languages are available for the school years subsequent to 1988-89, they will show a further improvement in the already favourable situation.

Qst.Quest: if she will consider a review of the second level school curriculum with a view to protecting the status of civics classes for all pupils for the entire duration of their second level education.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: if she intends to introduce, as a subject for examination, a meaningful civics course in second level schools; if such a subject will include topics like (1) the Constitution (2) citizens' rights (3) political systems and (4) central and local government; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 81 and 139 together.

Civic education is an important element of the newly introduced junior certificate programme, infusing all subjects, most notably history, geography, business studies and home economics. Civic education must incorporate not only knowledge but also attitudes, skills and understanding of political and social life.
The NCCA are preparing a civics syllabus for the first year of post-primary education. This syllabus is scheduled for early completion and implementation in schools.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: if, in view of the introduction of a six-year cycle for post-primary schools, she is prepared to allow for the increase in pupil numbers in the design plans for new school buildings so that adequate space is provided in all new buildings for the extra student numbers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The introduction of a six-year cycle for post-primary schools is one of a number of factors, which include demographic trends, housing provision, primary and post-primary school enrolments, that must be taken into account in the planning and design of new or improved school accommodation. It is only after consideration of all these factors that my Department can project short, medium and long term enrolments for schools and consequently plan how best to accommodate the pupils in question.

Qst.Quest: if she will confirm that funding will be provided in 1991 to commence construction on the community school at Castlerea, County Roscommon, given that all planning stages of this project are now complete.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sewage Disposal.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the procedures which apply where raw sewage is to be dumped following treatment at Ringsend.
if his attention has been drawn to the dumping of sewage off the coast of Howth, County Dublin; and if he will have this matter investigated.

if his attention has been drawn to the fact that sewage has been dumped off the Dalkey coastline; if he has satisfied himself that the coastline and waters near the shore will not be affected; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if he will outline the periodic testing of waters which is carried out where sewage is being disposed; and if he satisfied himself with the present procedures.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 87 to 90, inclusive, together. Sewage sludge from the Dublin Corporation treatment plant at Ringsend is dumped at sea in accordance with a permit granted by the Minister for the Marine under the Dumping at Sea Act, 1981. The terms and conditions of the permit govern dumping and monitoring and are reviewed annually by my Department.

At the beginning of this month the authorised dump site was relocated from its previous location two miles off Howth Head to a new site further offshore. It is intended that the new site, which is located some ten miles from the nearest coast, will receive about 300,000 tonnes of sewage sludge per annum until the dumping of sewage sludge at sea is phased out completely by 1998 in accordance with the Government's environment action programme.

MainHeading.P: The old and new dump sites have been carefully monitored and studied. The report of a study of the dump site off Howth Head, published by my Department in 1989, revealed a degree of localised fauna enrichment in the vicinity of the site but indicated that conditions on the sea floor had not deteriorated since 1983 when the last study was undertaken. The new site was chosen as the most suitable of a number of sites following extensive scientific studies. The report of the first phase of a four phase study to select a new site was published last year and I understand that the phases 2 and 3 reports will be made available shortly. All studies were undertaken on behalf of my Department and funded by Dublin Corporation. In addition, the sludge itself has been and continues to be subject to regular and detailed analyses to ensure the protection of the marine environment in the vicinities of the dump sites.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Passport Applications.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to a number of cases of people who have received Irish citizenship and in applying for an Irish passport are unable to supply the Passport Office with a copy of their birth certificate from their country of birth; and if he will outline the steps which can be taken to permit an Irish passport to be issued to persons in such circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: An Irish passport is a valuable document relating to the holder's Irish citizenship and identity. To preserve its integrity and international acceptability it is important to ensure that Irish passports are granted only to those properly entitled to hold them.

To ensure that applications are entertained only from those who are eligible for a passport, each adult applicant is required to produce to the Passport Office a completed application form and two photographs which have been certified by a garda, together with a birth certificate and any other proof of identity or citizenship as may be required.

MainHeading.P: I am aware that the requirement for a birth certificate has in the past caused problems for applicants who have acquired Irish citizenship other than by birth in this country. The Passport Office are prepared to examine all such applications sympathetically and accept substitute documentation in cases where it is established that birth certificates are not available from the country of birth of the applicant.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cambodia Situation.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to (1) the scale of the continuing conflict in Cambodia and (2) the fact that the UN currently holds $48.5 million for development in Cambodia; the steps which are being taken to alleviate the plight of the people there; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: I am deeply conscious of the continuing conflict in Cambodia and the human cost which the hostilities are exacting from the Cambodian people. Deputies will be aware that I have repeatedly called on the Cambodian parties to cease hostilities, most recently in my statements of 31 October and 6 December 1990 to the Dáil. Such a ceasefire would, in my view, greatly facilitate the successful implementation of the UN plan for a comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict. I urge the Cambodian parties to demonstrate flexibility and compromise in order that the UN plan can be implemented at the earliest possible time. The Cambodian people have suffered for too long and must be given the opportunity to live their lives in peace, free from the spectre of appalling violence and terror.

I am aware that the United Nations Development Programme has accumulated funds for development in Cambodia. The UNDP can co-operate only with governments recognised by the United Nations. The administration in Phnom Penh, which was installed by the occupying Vietnamese, is not so recognised.

MainHeading.P: As I stated in my reply to a similar question on 30 January last, both the UN and the EC continue to provide humanitarian aid to the Cambodian people. The UN aid is mainly concentrated on refugees from the conflict and channelled through UNBRO, the United Nations Border Relief Operation. This agency receives about $60 million per annum.

The latest figures on Community aid show that in 1990, 8.82 MECU was given in humanitarian aid for refugees on the Thai-Cambodian border. In addition, 2.67 MECU was provided to non-governmental organisations for emergency relief within the country (1.3 ECU = £1 approximately).

In September 1990, Ireland provided £25,000 to OXFAM for purchase of shelter kits for use by people displaced by fighting within Cambodia. In November 1989, £50,000 was given to CONCERN for emergency aid supplies. These contributions were designed to assist in alleviating the immediate plight of the Cambodian people.

The European Community has indicated its willingness, on the achievement of a political settlement, to contribute to the reconstruction and development of Cambodia. I can again assure Deputies that such assistance will have the full support of the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. A. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disposal of Raw Sewage.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that (1) the present regulations and procedures regarding the treatment and disposal of raw sewage and (2) the relevant EC regulations, are being adhered to; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Guidelines from my Department regarding the operation and maintenance of sewage treatment and disposal plants are in place and sanitary authorities are required to observe them.

Sewage effluent standards are envisaged in the draft EC Directive on municipal waste water, now under negotiation, and in section 58 of the Environmental Protection Agency Bill, 1990. The latter provides also for criteria and procedures to be specified by the new agency for the purposes of environmental protection in relation to the management, maintenance, supervision, operation and use of sewage plants.

I consider that this combination of existing and prospective guidelines and standards, together with expanded investment in sewage treatment under the environmental action programme will ensure the satisfactory treatment and disposal of all significant sewage discharges.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself with the present arrangement for the treatment and disposal of raw sewage from (1) Dublin Bay and (2) Dún Laoghaire; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: A large proportion of Dublin's effluent is discharged to Dublin Bay following primary treatment at Ringsend or preliminary treatment at Dún Laoghaire. Sewage is also discharged, following preliminary treatment, off the Head of Howth.

A major scheme to divert effluent from Dún Laoghaire is currently under construction and the initial phase of pumping the effluent via a submarine pipeline to Ringsend is due for completion in the coming months. The planning of the remaining contracts for the Bulloch and Coliemore areas are at an advanced stage.

In accordance with the Government's environment action programme and in anticipation of the EC Municipal Waste Water Directive I have approved briefs for consultants to prepare preliminary reports for secondary, and higher treatment if necessary, together with sludge management and disposal arrangements at Ringsend. Dublin Corporation have been instructed to develop suitable proposals at the earliest possible date.
Details of the improved treatment works and disposal arrangements proposed for the Howth discharge are set out in the reply to Question No. 20 of 7 March 1991.
These schemes when completed will significantly improve the quality of water in Dublin Bay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Importation of Reconditioned Ambulances.

Qst.Quest: if he proposes to import reconditioned secondhand ambulances from the United Kingdom or if he has any knowledge of ambulances being imported by health boards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: Responsibility for the provision of ambulances lies with the health boards in the first instance.

I understand that a number of health boards are in the process of purchasing ten ambulance vehicles from a health authority in the United Kingdom to supplement their ambulance fleet. The health boards concerned have obtained the services of a qualified independent vehicle assessor to carry out a detailed thorough examination of the vehicles to ensure safety and road worthiness.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Six Year School Cycle.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: when the details of the six year cycle will be related to school managers; whether the six year cycle will be compulsory for all students; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Programme for Economic and Social Progress provides for an optional six year cycle for all pupils commencing their post-primary education in 1991. The second level cycle will consist of three years at junior level and the option of a transition year before a two year senior cycle.
The National Council for Curriculum and Assessment are at present examining the structure of the senior cycle and I am awaiting their recommendations in this regard.
The situation has been outlined to managerial authorities at informal meetings with my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Schools.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if she will outline in respect of (a) primary level and (b) post-primary schools (i) the number of schools designated as disadvantaged for the first time in 1990, (ii) the location of these schools by county, (iii) the additional staffing and funding allocated to these schools, (iv) whether these schools will retain this designation, (v) the number of schools which it is expected will be designated disadvantaged by the end of 1991 and (vi) the total number and proportion of such schools now so designated at primary and post-primary level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The position in relation to primary schools is that arising from the recommendations of a representative working party which reported in 1990, criteria have now been established for the designation of schools as disadvantaged for the purpose of the allocation of additional resources.
These criteria assume that there are greater and lesser degrees of disadvantage rather than an absolute indicator classifying schools as disadvantaged or not disadvantaged.

MainHeading.P: There are currently 188 schools designated as disadvantaged for the purpose of additional resource allocation. Each of these schools, with the exception of seven schools where numbers are small, was allocated an additional teaching post together with additional funding of £5 per pupil for equipment and materials, £10 per pupil for school operating costs and, where these exist, £2 per pupil in respect of home/school liaison schemes. The location of the schools by county is as follows:
Retention of designation as disadvantaged will be related to the operation of the criteria.
It cannot be stated at this time how many schools will be designated by end 1991.
The 188 schools comprise 5.7 per cent of primary schools. The 58,000 pupils in these schools comprise 10.6 per cent of pupils in those schools.

The position in relation to the second level sector is as follows: (i) my Department have not drawn up a list of post-primary schools designated as disadvantaged but have information on approximately 75 per cent of all post-primary schools which shows relative disadvantage, by reference to agreed criteria, as between such schools. Accordingly the concept of what proportion of schools are designated as “disadvantaged” does not arise. My Department allocated an additional 60 teachers to schools nationwide for the 1990-91 school year under a scheme of assistance to post-primary schools in disadvantaged areas. The posts were allocated on the basis of agreed criteria drawn up by a working party representative of school authorities, teacher unions, parents' interests and my Department; (ii) the schools benefiting under the scheme were located in the following counties:

(iii) In each case, schools were authorised to employ an additional permanent teacher; (iv) there are no plans to withdraw these teachers. Schools which have been allocated an additional teacher under the scheme of assistance will be entitled to retain this teacher for as long as an established need exists; and (v) a further 60 posts will be allocated to post-primary schools in disadvantaged areas for the 1991-92 school year in accordance with the provisions of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The 1991 grant to the Olympic Council of Ireland for the preparation and training of athletes for the Olympic Games in Barcelona next year has not yet been decided. Speaker.P: The information required by the Deputy is given in tabular form below.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teacher In-service Courses.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline the expenses she is paying to teachers attending in-service courses; her views on whether these amounts are adequate; and if she envisages increasing these rates.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In the case of primary schools, Department organised in-service courses are provided free of charge and teachers are not paid expenses to attend such courses or other in-service courses. Teachers who attend in-service summer courses are entitled to up to three days extra personal vacation in the following school year.

MainHeading.P: In the case of second level teachers revised rates of expenses for attendance at in-service courses organised by my Department were introduced with effect from 1 January 1991. The new rates are as follows:
Subsistence allowance per night:
Block release courses in Remedial Education: £19.91; Other courses: £12.07.
Travel allowance

Payable at the lowest bus or train rate. If public transport is not available, 21p per mile is payable as a car allowance. In addition, teachers attending the one-day junior certificate courses are provided with a midday meal.
A circular announcing the new travel and subsistence rates is being issued to schools at present and I am arranging for a copy to be sent to the Deputy.
